articles.title: Homeowners affected by the 2023 Maui wildfires: Here’s how to keep and rebuild your home
articles.content:
Homeowners affected by the 2023 Maui wildfires: Here’s how to keep and rebuild your home

Two years after the devastating 2023 Maui wildfires, homeowners may be facing the prospect of repaying mortgage loans previously in forbearance. Grist has compiled tips and resources to help homeowners avoid foreclosure.

Funding for homeowners affected by the 2023 Maui wildfires

Maui County’s CDBG Funding: This newly approved federal funding provides money for homeowners to rebuild in a fire-impacted area; up to $400,000 reimbursements for homeowners who already rebuilt their homes; and up to $600,000 for a fire survivor to buy a new home. Applications are now open. Click here to learn more about these community development block grants, including income requirements or email support@mauirecovers.com.

This newly approved federal funding provides money for homeowners to rebuild in a fire-impacted area; up to $400,000 reimbursements for homeowners who already rebuilt their homes; and up to $600,000 for a fire survivor to buy a new home. Applications are now open. Click here to learn more about these community development block grants, including income requirements or email support@mauirecovers.com. Habitat for Humanity: This nonprofit is offering $100,000 for homeowners whose insurance payments fell short and need money to rebuild. Eligibility is limited to those whose incomes are below Maui County’s area median income, which varies depending on household size. Call 808-242-1140, email homes@habitat-maui.org, or visit the website to learn if you qualify.

This nonprofit is offering $100,000 for homeowners whose insurance payments fell short and need money to rebuild. Eligibility is limited to those whose incomes are below Maui County’s area median income, which varies depending on household size. Call 808-242-1140, email homes@habitat-maui.org, or visit the website to learn if you qualify. Lāhainā Community Land Trust: For homeowners on the brink of foreclosure, the Lāhainā Community Land Trust can purchase your property to maintain local community ownership, rebuild your home, and then sell the house back to you so that you can continue to live there. Families can also obtain 99-year renewable leases on the land beneath their homes, which they can pass down to their children. Call 808-830-LCLT, email info@lahainacommunitylandtrust.org, or read more about the program here.

Call 808-830-LCLT, email info@lahainacommunitylandtrust.org, or read more about the program here. Hawaii Community Lending — This nonprofit offers a myriad of resources, including grant funding, through the Lāhainā Homeowner Recovery Program for Lāhainā owner-occupant homeowners who are looking to prevent foreclosure and rebuild. Call 808-587-7656, email HCL@hawaiicommunitylending.com or click here to learn more.

Tips on dealing with your mortgage servicer

Be persistent. Mikey Burke, a Lāhainā homeowner, said she calls her mortgage servicer, Mr. Cooper, every few months and is consistently told that she’s reached the maximum amount of time for disaster forbearance. But she doesn’t accept that, after hearing otherwise from her mortgage owner, Fannie Mae. “Whenever I call Mr. Cooper and ask to extend, the first answer is always no and then I have to ask to escalate.” She has extended her forbearance through November 2025.

articles.personality_title: New funds and programs help Maui wildfire homeowners rebuild and stay in their homes
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In 2023, wildfires severely damaged homes across Maui, leaving many families struggling to rebuild and keep their properties. Two years later, some homeowners face the challenge of repaying paused mortgage loans and risk losing their homes.

**What happened** – The government and nonprofits have created several programs to support these homeowners. Maui County offers federal grants that can provide up to $400,000 to reimburse rebuilding costs or $600,000 to buy a new home. Habitat for Humanity gives $100,000 to those whose insurance did not cover all damages, and the Lāhainā Community Land Trust helps families avoid foreclosure by buying and rebuilding homes, then selling them back with long-term leases. Hawaii Community Lending also offers grants and support for rebuilding.

**Impact** – These programs are unique because they not only provide money to rebuild but also help keep homes in the community. The land trust’s option to lease land for 99 years means families can stay in their homes for generations. This support prevents many families from losing their homes and helps rebuild the community’s foundation.

**What's next step** – Homeowners can now apply for these programs and seek help from nonprofit counselors certified by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development. They are encouraged to stay persistent with mortgage companies and use state resources if they face difficulties. These steps aim to help homeowners fully recover and rebuild safely.

**One-sentence takeaway** – New federal and nonprofit programs offer important financial help and housing solutions to Maui wildfire survivors, supporting their recovery and keeping communities strong.
articles.personality_title_fr: De nouveaux fonds et programmes aident les propriétaires sinistrés à Maui à reconstruire et rester chez eux
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En 2023, des incendies ont gravement endommagé des maisons à Maui, laissant de nombreuses familles en difficulté pour reconstruire et conserver leur logement. Deux ans plus tard, certains doivent rembourser des prêts hypothécaires suspendus et risquent de perdre leur maison.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le gouvernement et des associations ont mis en place plusieurs programmes pour soutenir ces propriétaires. Le comté de Maui propose des subventions fédérales allant jusqu’à 400 000 $ pour rembourser les coûts de reconstruction ou 600 000 $ pour acheter une nouvelle maison. Habitat for Humanity offre 100 000 $ à ceux dont l’assurance n’a pas tout couvert, et le Lāhainā Community Land Trust aide les familles à éviter la saisie en achetant et reconstruisant les maisons, puis en les revendant avec des baux à long terme. Hawaii Community Lending propose aussi des subventions et un soutien pour la reconstruction.

**Impact** – Ces programmes sont uniques car ils apportent non seulement de l’argent pour reconstruire, mais aident aussi à maintenir les maisons dans la communauté. L’option de bail de 99 ans permet aux familles de rester chez elles pendant des générations. Ce soutien empêche beaucoup de familles de perdre leur maison et aide à reconstruire la communauté.

**Prochaine étape** – Les propriétaires peuvent désormais postuler à ces programmes et demander de l’aide à des conseillers sans but lucratif certifiés par le Département américain du logement. Ils sont encouragés à être persistants avec leurs sociétés hypothécaires et à utiliser les ressources de l’État en cas de difficulté. Ces mesures visent à aider les propriétaires à se remettre complètement et à reconstruire en toute sécurité.

**Une phrase clé** – De nouveaux programmes fédéraux et associatifs offrent une aide financière importante et des solutions de logement aux survivants des incendies de Maui, soutenant leur rétablissement et la solidité des communautés.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevos fondos y programas ayudan a los propietarios afectados en Maui a reconstruir y mantener sus hogares
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En 2023, incendios devastadores dañaron muchas casas en Maui, dejando a muchas familias con dificultades para reconstruir y conservar sus hogares. Dos años después, algunos propietarios enfrentan la posibilidad de tener que pagar préstamos hipotecarios que habían sido suspendidos y corren el riesgo de perder sus casas.

**Qué pasó** – El gobierno y organizaciones sin fines de lucro crearon varios programas para apoyar a estos propietarios. El condado de Maui ofrece subvenciones federales que pueden cubrir hasta 400,000 dólares para reembolsar costos de reconstrucción o 600,000 dólares para comprar una nueva casa. Habitat for Humanity ofrece 100,000 dólares a quienes su seguro no cubrió todos los daños, y el Lāhainā Community Land Trust ayuda a las familias a evitar la ejecución hipotecaria comprando y reconstruyendo casas para luego venderlas con contratos de arrendamiento a largo plazo. Hawaii Community Lending también ofrece subvenciones y apoyo para la reconstrucción.

**Impacto** – Estos programas son especiales porque no solo dan dinero para reconstruir, sino que también ayudan a mantener las casas dentro de la comunidad. La opción de arrendamiento por 99 años permite que las familias permanezcan en sus hogares por generaciones. Este apoyo evita que muchas familias pierdan sus casas y ayuda a reconstruir la comunidad.

**Próximo paso** – Los propietarios pueden solicitar estos programas y buscar ayuda de consejeros sin fines de lucro certificados por el Departamento de Vivienda de EE.UU. Se recomienda que sean persistentes con las compañías hipotecarias y usen recursos estatales si tienen problemas. Estos pasos buscan que los propietarios puedan recuperarse completamente y reconstruir de forma segura.

**Una frase clave** – Nuevos programas federales y sin fines de lucro brindan ayuda financiera importante y soluciones de vivienda a los sobrevivientes de los incendios en Maui, apoyando su recuperación y fortaleciendo las comunidades.

articles.title: These ants are one of the most effective teams in the natural world
articles.summary: Typically, individuals work less effectively in bigger teams, but weaver ants buck this trend by increasing their power output when they pull together
articles.content:
Typically, individuals work less effectively in bigger teams, but weaver ants buck this trend by increasing their power output when they pull together

Weaver ants folding paper Dr Chris Reid, Macquarie University

A chain of weaver ants can easily outpull just about any other creature, pound for pound, making them one of the most formidable teams in the animal kingdom.

Weaver ants (Oecophylla smaragdina), which are found from India to northern Australia, form long chains to pull on leaves to roll them up for building their nests. They lock themselves together by using their mandibles to hold onto the abdomen of the ant in front.

Advertisement

To determine just how strong they are, Chris Reid at Macquarie University in Sydney, Australia, and his colleagues offered weaver ants paper leaves instead of real ones to build a nest. They attached a transducer to the tip of the paper leaf to measure the amount of force that groups of up to 17 ants were applying when they rolled up the paper.

The researchers found that individual ants can generate an average of nearly 60 times their own body weight in pulling force, but in a team of 15, each individual was able to pull over 100 times their body weight. This means that the average force contribution per individual almost doubled in the team.

Free newsletter Sign up to The Earth Edition Unmissable news about our planet, delivered straight to your inbox each month. Sign up to newsletter

This result appears to contradict a longstanding principle of teamwork known as the Ringelmann effect, in which the bigger a group, the less productive each individual becomes. This is thought to be because individuals in a group lose both coordination and motivation.

While the researchers didn’t do the maths on how weaver ants would perform relative to humans, Reid says they would make a formidable foe in a tug of war, even if they weren’t scaled up to human size. “Even at guinea pig size, weaver ants might be able to outcompete humans in a tug of war match,” he says. “But their greatest advantage is having six legs and having really good contact with the ground on each of those legs.”

That may be part of the reason why they are able to buck the Ringelmann effect, says Reid. Although the exact mechanisms behind their group power are yet to be fully understood, one idea is that some of the ants in the chain lock onto the ground while the others pull, creating a kind of force ratchet.

“When you compare weaver ants to other species, their attachment force with the ground is off the charts. It’s an order of magnitude greater than other ants,” says Reid.

Journal reference: Current Biology DOI: 10.1016/j.cub.2025.07.038
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a significant biological discovery about weaver ants' unique teamwork and strength, which challenges existing scientific understanding of group dynamics (Ringelmann effect). This insight into natural teamwork and biomechanics has broad scientific interest and could inspire further research or biomimetic applications, offering meaningful knowledge with potential real-world benefits.
articles.personality_title: Weaver ants show incredible teamwork by pulling stronger together
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Usually, when people or animals work in bigger teams, each member tends to do less work. This is called the Ringelmann effect. But scientists found that weaver ants don’t follow this rule.

**What happened** – Researchers at Macquarie University in Australia studied weaver ants, which live from India to northern Australia. These ants build nests by pulling leaves together in long chains, holding onto each other with their jaws. The scientists measured how much force groups of ants could pull using paper leaves and a special tool. They found that a single ant can pull about 60 times its own weight, but in a group of 15, each ant pulled more than 100 times its weight.

**Impact** – This discovery is important because it shows that weaver ants get stronger when they work together, unlike most animals or humans. Their teamwork is so good that they can pull much more weight than expected. Scientists think this might be because some ants hold tightly to the ground while others pull, making their effort more powerful.

**What's next step** – Researchers want to understand exactly how weaver ants achieve this strength and teamwork. Learning from these ants might help design better robots or machines that work well together, inspired by nature.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Weaver ants break the usual teamwork rules by pulling much harder together than alone, showing a unique natural power in groups.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les fourmis tisserandes montrent une force incroyable en travaillant ensemble
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Habituellement, quand des personnes ou des animaux travaillent en équipe plus grande, chaque membre fait moins d'efforts. Cela s'appelle l'effet Ringelmann. Mais les scientifiques ont découvert que les fourmis tisserandes ne suivent pas cette règle.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des chercheurs de l'Université Macquarie en Australie ont étudié les fourmis tisserandes, qui vivent de l'Inde au nord de l'Australie. Ces fourmis construisent leurs nids en tirant des feuilles ensemble en longues chaînes, se tenant les unes aux autres avec leurs mandibules. Les scientifiques ont mesuré la force qu'elles pouvaient exercer en tirant sur des feuilles en papier avec un outil spécial. Ils ont trouvé qu'une fourmi seule peut tirer environ 60 fois son poids, mais dans un groupe de 15, chaque fourmi tire plus de 100 fois son poids.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est importante car elle montre que les fourmis tisserandes deviennent plus fortes en travaillant ensemble, contrairement à la plupart des animaux ou des humains. Leur travail d'équipe est si efficace qu'elles peuvent tirer beaucoup plus que prévu. Les scientifiques pensent que cela vient du fait que certaines fourmis tiennent bien le sol pendant que d'autres tirent, ce qui rend leur effort plus puissant.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs veulent comprendre exactement comment les fourmis tisserandes arrivent à cette force et ce travail d'équipe. Apprendre d'elles pourrait aider à créer de meilleurs robots ou machines qui travaillent bien ensemble, en s'inspirant de la nature.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les fourmis tisserandes défient les règles habituelles du travail en équipe en tirant beaucoup plus fort ensemble que seules, montrant une force naturelle unique en groupe.
articles.personality_title_es: Las hormigas tejedoras demuestran una fuerza increíble al trabajar juntas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Normalmente, cuando personas o animales trabajan en equipos más grandes, cada miembro hace menos esfuerzo. Esto se llama el efecto Ringelmann. Pero los científicos descubrieron que las hormigas tejedoras no siguen esta regla.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad Macquarie en Australia estudiaron a las hormigas tejedoras, que viven desde India hasta el norte de Australia. Estas hormigas construyen sus nidos tirando hojas juntas en largas cadenas, sujetándose unas a otras con sus mandíbulas. Los científicos midieron la fuerza que grupos de hormigas podían hacer al tirar de hojas de papel con una herramienta especial. Encontraron que una hormiga sola puede tirar unas 60 veces su peso, pero en un grupo de 15, cada hormiga tiraba más de 100 veces su peso.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento es importante porque muestra que las hormigas tejedoras se hacen más fuertes cuando trabajan juntas, a diferencia de la mayoría de animales o humanos. Su trabajo en equipo es tan bueno que pueden tirar mucho más peso del esperado. Los científicos creen que esto puede ser porque algunas hormigas se agarran fuerte al suelo mientras otras tiran, haciendo su esfuerzo más poderoso.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores quieren entender exactamente cómo las hormigas tejedoras logran esta fuerza y trabajo en equipo. Aprender de ellas podría ayudar a diseñar mejores robots o máquinas que trabajen bien en grupo, inspirados en la naturaleza.

**Resumen en una frase** – Las hormigas tejedoras rompen las reglas normales del trabajo en equipo al tirar mucho más fuerte juntas que solas, mostrando un poder natural único en grupos.
